extracted_concepts.definition: A numerical value representing a creature's physical and mental resilience and vitality.

rule_logic.premise: A creature has a current and maximum number of hit points
rule_logic.implication: Current hit points decrease when damage is taken; reaching 0 hit points leads to unconsciousness and potential death.
rule_logic.description_text: Hit points are a measure of a creature's health and resilience. When a creature takes damage, its hit points decrease. When a creature's hit points drop to 0, it falls unconscious and is in danger of dying.
related_search_terms: how much damage can I take

extracted_concepts.definition: The process by which a creature's hit points are reduced due to harm.

rule_logic.premise: A creature suffers damage
rule_logic.implication: Reduce the creature's current hit points by the damage amount. If hit points reach 0, follow rules for 0 Hit Points.
rule_logic.description_text: Whenever a creature takes damage, subtract that damage from its current hit points. When a creature's hit points drop to 0, it falls unconscious and is in danger of dying, unless the damage kills it outright.

extracted_concepts.definition: The state a creature enters when its hit points are reduced to zero.

rule_logic.premise: A creature's current hit points are reduced to 0 (and not killed outright)
rule_logic.implication: The creature falls unconscious, drops whatever it's holding, and begins making death saving throws at the start of its turns.
rule_logic.description_text: When your hit points drop to 0, you fall unconscious. This unconsciousness ends if you regain any hit points. Unless the damage kills you outright, you are not dead. You're dying. At the start of your turn, you must make a special saving throw, called a death saving throw.

extracted_concepts.definition: A specific condition causing a creature to die immediately upon taking damage, bypassing death saving throws.

rule_logic.premise: Damage reduces a creature's hit points to 0, AND the excess damage (damage beyond what was needed to reach 0) is equal to or greater than its hit point maximum
rule_logic.implication: The creature dies instantly.
rule_logic.description_text: When damage reduces you to 0 hit points and there is damage remaining, you die if the remaining damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special saving throw made by a dying creature to determine its fate: stabilization or death.

rule_logic.premise: A creature is at 0 hit points and not stable, at the start of its turn
rule_logic.implication: The creature makes a d20 roll without modifiers. A result of 10 or higher is a success, 9 or lower is a failure. Accumulate 3 successes to stabilize, or 3 failures to die. A natural 20 restores 1 HP. A natural 1 counts as 2 failures.
rule_logic.description_text: Whenever you start your turn with 0 hit points, you must make a special saving throw, called a death saving throw, to determine whether you cling to life or embrace death. Unlike other saving throws, this one isn't tied to any of your ability scores. You are in the hands of fate now, so roll a d20. If the roll is 10 or higher, you succeed. Otherwise, you fail. A success or failure has no effect by itself. Instead, you keep track of both. On your third success, you become stable. On your third failure, you die. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of both until you collect three of a kind. If you roll a 1 on the d20, it counts as two failures. If you roll a 20 on the d20, you regain 1 hit point.

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of ending the dying state of a creature at 0 hit points, preventing further death saving throws.

rule_logic.premise: A creature at 0 hit points needs to be stabilized, AND an action is used (e.g., successfully making a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check)
rule_logic.implication: The creature becomes stable. It is still at 0 hit points and unconscious, but no longer makes death saving throws. It regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.
rule_logic.description_text: The best way to save a creature at 0 hit points is to heal it. If it regains any hit points, it is no longer in danger of death. A stable creature doesn't make death saving throws, even though it has 0 hit points, but it does remain unconscious. The creature stops being stable, and must start making death saving throws again, if it takes any damage. A stable creature that isn't healed regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.

extracted_concepts.definition: A measure representing a creature's physical and mental durability, will to live, and luck, indicating how difficult it is to kill.

rule_logic.premise: A creature exists
rule_logic.implication: Creature possesses Hit Points, a numerical value between its hit point maximum and 0
rule_logic.description_text: Hit points represent a combination of physical and mental durability, the will to live, and luck. A creature's current hit points can be any number from the creature's hit point maximum down to 0.

extracted_concepts.definition: The process of reducing a creature's hit points when it takes damage.

rule_logic.premise: Creature takes damage
rule_logic.implication: Damage value is subtracted from the creature's current hit points
rule_logic.description_text: Whenever a creature takes damage, that damage is subtracted from its hit points.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Effect of Hit Point Loss (above 0 HP)
extracted_concepts.definition: The impact of a creature losing hit points while still having more than 0 hit points remaining.

rule_logic.premise: Creature loses hit points AND current hit points remain above 0
rule_logic.implication: No effect on the creature's capabilities
rule_logic.description_text: The loss of hit points has no effect on a creature's capabilities until the creature drops to 0 hit points.

extracted_concepts.definition: The dynamic nature of a creature's current hit points, changing based on events like damage and healing.

rule_logic.premise: Creature takes damage OR creature receives healing
rule_logic.implication: Creature's current hit points change accordingly
rule_logic.description_text: This number [current hit points] changes frequently as a creature takes damage or receives healing.

extracted_concepts.definition: The process of determining the amount of damage dealt by an attack or harmful effect.

rule_logic.premise: An attack, spell, or harmful monster ability deals damage
rule_logic.implication: Roll the specified damage dice, add any modifiers, and apply the total damage to the target
rule_logic.description_text: Each weapon, spell, and harmful monster ability specifies the damage it deals. You roll the damage die or dice, add any modifiers, and apply the damage to your target. Magic weapons, special abilities, and other factors can grant a bonus to damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: The ability modifier added to a weapon's damage roll.

rule_logic.premise: Attacking with a weapon
rule_logic.implication: Add the ability modifier (the same one used for the attack roll) to the damage roll
rule_logic.description_text: When attacking with a weapon, you add your ability modifier-the same modifier used for the attack roll-to the damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: The specific dice and modifiers determined by a spell for its damage.

rule_logic.premise: Casting a spell that deals damage
rule_logic.implication: The spell's description specifies which dice to roll for damage and whether to add any modifiers
rule_logic.description_text: A spell tells you which dice to roll for damage and whether to add any modifiers.

extracted_concepts.definition: The lowest possible damage value that can be dealt after all modifiers and penalties.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is being dealt, potentially with penalties
rule_logic.implication: Damage dealt can be 0, but never a negative number
rule_logic.description_text: With a penalty, it is possible to deal 0 damage, but never negative damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: The method for rolling damage when an effect simultaneously harms multiple creatures.

rule_logic.premise: A spell or other effect deals damage to more than one target at the same time
rule_logic.implication: Roll the damage dice once, and that single result applies to all affected targets
rule_logic.description_text: If a spell or other effect deals damage to more than one target at the same time, roll the damage once for all of them. For example, when a wizard casts fireball or a cleric casts flame strike, the spell's damage is rolled once for all creatures caught in the blast.

extracted_concepts.definition: The special damage calculation performed when an attack scores a critical hit against a target.

rule_logic.premise: An attack scores a critical hit
rule_logic.implication: Roll all of the attack's damage dice twice (including additional damage dice like Sneak Attack), add them together, and then add any relevant modifiers as normal
rule_logic.description_text: When you score a critical hit, you get to roll extra dice for the attack's damage against the target. Roll all of the attack's damage dice twice and add them together. Then add any relevant modifiers as normal. To speed up play, you can roll all the damage dice at once. For example, if you score a critical hit with a dagger, roll 2d4 for the damage, rather than 1d4, and then add your relevant ability modifier. If the attack involves other damage dice, such as from the rogue's Sneak Attack feature, you roll those dice twice as well.

extracted_concepts.definition: Categories used to classify different forms of damage, which other rules (like resistance) may interact with.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt
rule_logic.implication: The damage has a specific type (e.g., Acid, Bludgeoning, Fire, etc.). Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules rely on them.
rule_logic.description_text: Different attacks, damaging spells, and other harmful effects deal different types of damage. Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as damage resistance, rely on the types.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from corrosive substances.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by corrosive effects
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as acid damage
rule_logic.description_text: The corrosive spray of a black dragon's breath and the dissolving enzymes secreted by a black pudding deal acid damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from blunt force attacks.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by blunt force
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as bludgeoning damage
rule_logic.description_text: Blunt force attacks-hammers, falling, constriction, and the like-deal bludgeoning damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from frigid temperatures or icy effects.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by frigid or icy effects
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as cold damage
rule_logic.description_text: The infernal chill radiating from an ice devil's spear and the frigid blast of a white dragon's breath deal cold damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from flames or intense heat.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by flames or intense heat
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as fire damage
rule_logic.description_text: Red dragons breathe fire, and many spells conjure flames to deal fire damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from pure magical energy.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by pure magical energy
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as force damage
rule_logic.description_text: Force is pure magical energy focused into a damaging form. Most effects that deal force damage are spells, including magic missile and spiritual weapon.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from electrical discharge.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by electrical discharge
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as lightning damage
rule_logic.description_text: A lightning bolt spell and a blue dragon's breath deal lightning damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage that withers matter and the soul, often associated with undeath.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by effects that wither matter or the soul
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as necrotic damage
rule_logic.description_text: Necrotic damage, dealt by certain undead and a spell such as chill touch, withers matter and even the soul.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from puncturing or impaling attacks.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by puncturing or impaling attacks
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as piercing damage
rule_logic.description_text: Puncturing and impaling attacks, including spears and monsters' bites, deal piercing damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from venomous or toxic substances.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by venomous or toxic substances
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as poison damage
rule_logic.description_text: Venomous stings and the toxic gas of a green dragon's breath deal poison damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from mental attacks or psionic energy.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by mental attacks or psionic energy
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as psychic damage
rule_logic.description_text: Mental abilities such as a mind flayer's psionic blast deal psychic damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage that sears flesh and overloads the spirit, often divine or holy in nature.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by searing or spirit-overloading effects
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as radiant damage
rule_logic.description_text: Radiant damage, dealt by a cleric's flame strike spell or an angel's smiting weapon, sears the flesh like fire and overloads the spirit with power.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from cutting attacks.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by cutting attacks
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as slashing damage
rule_logic.description_text: Swords, axes, and monsters' claws deal slashing damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: Damage from concussive bursts of sound.

rule_logic.premise: Damage is dealt by concussive sound
rule_logic.implication: It is classified as thunder damage
rule_logic.description_text: A concussive burst of sound, such as the effect of the thunderwave spell, deals thunder damage.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition where a creature or object takes half damage from a specific damage type.

rule_logic.premise: A creature or an object has resistance to a specific damage type AND takes damage of that type
rule_logic.implication: Damage of that type is halved against the target. This halving occurs after all other modifiers to damage are applied. Multiple instances of resistance to the same damage type count as only one instance.
rule_logic.description_text: If a creature or an object has resistance to a damage type, damage of that type is halved against it. Resistance and then vulnerability are applied after all other modifiers to damage. Multiple instances of resistance or vulnerability that affect the same damage type count as only one instance.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition where a creature or object takes double damage from a specific damage type.

rule_logic.premise: A creature or an object has vulnerability to a specific damage type AND takes damage of that type
rule_logic.implication: Damage of that type is doubled against the target. This doubling occurs after all other modifiers to damage are applied. Multiple instances of vulnerability to the same damage type count as only one instance.
rule_logic.description_text: If a creature or an object has vulnerability to a damage type, damage of that type is doubled against it. Resistance and then vulnerability are applied after all other modifiers to damage. Multiple instances of resistance or vulnerability that affect the same damage type count as only one instance.

extracted_concepts.definition: The general procedure for how hit points are restored to a creature, adding regained hit points to its current total.

rule_logic.premise: A creature receives healing of any kind
rule_logic.implication: Hit points regained are added to its current hit points
rule_logic.description_text: When a creature receives healing of any kind, hit points regained are added to its current hit points.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Hit Point Maximum Limit for Healing
extracted_concepts.definition: A constraint preventing a creature's current hit points from exceeding its maximum hit points through healing.

rule_logic.premise: Healing would cause a creature's current hit points to exceed its hit point maximum
rule_logic.implication: Any hit points regained in excess of the creature's hit point maximum are lost
rule_logic.description_text: A creature's hit points can't exceed its hit point maximum, so any hit points regained in excess of this number are lost. For example, a druid grants a ranger 8 hit points of healing. If the ranger has 14 current hit points and has a hit point maximum of 20, the ranger regains 6 hit points from the druid, not 8.

extracted_concepts.definition: A specific rule stating that dead creatures cannot regain hit points until they are brought back to life by powerful magic.

rule_logic.premise: A creature has died
rule_logic.implication: The creature cannot regain hit points
exceptions: Unless magic such as the *revivify* spell has restored it to life
rule_logic.description_text: A creature that has died can't regain hit points until magic such as the *revivify* spell has restored it to life.

extracted_concepts.definition: The immediate consequence when a creature's current hit points are reduced to zero.

rule_logic.premise: Creature's current hit points are reduced to 0
rule_logic.implication: Creature either dies outright OR falls unconscious
rule_logic.description_text: When you drop to 0 hit points, you either die outright or fall unconscious, as explained in the following sections.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition where a creature dies immediately if damage reduces it to 0 hit points and the remaining damage exceeds its hit point maximum.

rule_logic.premise: Damage reduces target to 0 hit points AND remaining damage equals or exceeds target's hit point maximum
rule_logic.implication: Target dies instantly
rule_logic.description_text: When damage reduces you to 0 hit points and there is damage remaining, you die if the remaining damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum.

extracted_concepts.definition: The state a creature enters if damage reduces it to 0 hit points without resulting in instant death.

rule_logic.premise: Damage reduces target to 0 hit points AND target does not die instantly
rule_logic.implication: Target falls unconscious
rule_logic.description_text: If damage reduces you to 0 hit points and fails to kill you, you fall unconscious (see appendix PH-A). This unconsciousness ends if you regain any hit points.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special saving throw made at the start of a creature's turn when it has 0 hit points, used to determine if it stabilizes or dies.

rule_logic.premise: Creature starts its turn with 0 hit points
rule_logic.implication: Creature must make a death saving throw (Roll a d20. 10+ is success, <10 is failure. 3 successes = stable. 3 failures = death. Success/failure count resets on regaining HP or becoming stable.)
exceptions: Rolling a 1 on death saving throw
Rolling a 20 on death saving throw
rule_logic.description_text: Whenever you start your turn with 0 hit points, you must make a special saving throw, called a death saving throw, to determine whether you creep closer to death or hang onto life. Roll a d20. If the roll is 10 or higher, you succeed. Otherwise, you fail. A success or failure has no effect by itself. On your third success, you become stable (see below). On your third failure, you die. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of both until you collect three of a kind. The number of both is reset to zero when you regain any hit points or become stable.
related_search_terms: what is a death saving throw

extracted_concepts.definition: The specific consequence of rolling a natural 1 on a death saving throw.

rule_logic.premise: Creature makes a death saving throw AND rolls a 1 on the d20
rule_logic.implication: Counts as two failures
rule_logic.description_text: When you make a death saving throw and roll a 1 on the d20, it counts as two failures.

extracted_concepts.definition: The specific consequence of rolling a natural 20 on a death saving throw.

rule_logic.premise: Creature makes a death saving throw AND rolls a 20 on the d20
rule_logic.implication: Creature regains 1 hit point
rule_logic.description_text: If you roll a 20 on the d20, you regain 1 hit point.

extracted_concepts.definition: The effect of taking damage while a creature is at 0 hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Creature with 0 hit points takes any damage
rule_logic.implication: Creature suffers one death saving throw failure
rule_logic.description_text: If you take any damage while you have 0 hit points, you suffer a death saving throw failure.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Damage at 0 Hit Points: Critical Hit
extracted_concepts.definition: The specific effect of taking damage from a critical hit while a creature is at 0 hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Creature with 0 hit points takes damage from a critical hit
rule_logic.implication: Creature suffers two death saving throw failures
rule_logic.description_text: If the damage is from a critical hit, you suffer two failures instead.

extracted_concepts.concept_name: Damage at 0 Hit Points: Instant Death from Massive Damage
extracted_concepts.definition: The specific effect of taking massive damage while a creature is at 0 hit points, leading to instant death.

rule_logic.premise: Creature with 0 hit points takes damage AND the damage equals or exceeds its hit point maximum
rule_logic.implication: Creature suffers instant death
rule_logic.description_text: If the damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum, you suffer instant death.

extracted_concepts.definition: The act of administering first aid to an unconscious creature at 0 hit points to prevent further death saving throws.

rule_logic.premise: An unconscious creature has 0 hit points
rule_logic.implication: A character can use their action to attempt to stabilize it by making a successful DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check. On success, the creature becomes stable.
rule_logic.description_text: You can use your action to administer first aid to an unconscious creature and attempt to stabilize it, which requires a successful DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check.

extracted_concepts.definition: A condition for a creature at 0 hit points where it no longer makes death saving throws but remains unconscious.

rule_logic.premise: A creature is stable
rule_logic.implication: Creature does not make death saving throws; creature remains unconscious. If it takes any damage, it stops being stable and must start making death saving throws again. If not healed, it regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.
rule_logic.description_text: A **stable** creature doesn't make death saving throws, even though it has 0 hit points, but it does remain unconscious. The creature stops being stable, and must start making death saving throws again, if it takes any damage. A stable creature that isn't healed regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.

extracted_concepts.definition: The general rule for how monsters are handled upon reaching 0 hit points.

rule_logic.premise: A monster is reduced to 0 hit points (unless GM decides otherwise)
rule_logic.implication: Monster dies instantly
rule_logic.description_text: Most GMs have a monster die the instant it drops to 0 hit points, rather than having it fall unconscious and make death saving throws.

extracted_concepts.definition: An exception to the general monster death rule, allowing important monsters or NPCs to follow player character death rules.

rule_logic.premise: Monster is a mighty villain or special nonplayer character (DM's discretion)
rule_logic.implication: Monster might fall unconscious and follow the same rules as player characters (e.g., make death saving throws)
rule_logic.description_text: Mighty villains and special nonplayer characters are common exceptions; the GM might have them fall unconscious and follow the same rules as player characters.

extracted_concepts.definition: A specific choice an attacker can make to render a foe unconscious and stable, rather than dealing a killing blow, when reducing them to 0 hit points with a melee attack.

rule_logic.premise: IF an attacker reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack AND the attacker chooses to incapacitate
rule_logic.implication: THEN the creature falls unconscious AND is stable
rule_logic.description_text: When an attacker reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack, the attacker can knock the creature out. The attacker can make this choice the instant the damage is dealt. The creature falls unconscious and is stable.

extracted_concepts.definition: A buffer against damage, a pool of hit points that protect a creature from injury, distinct from actual hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has temporary hit points AND takes damage
rule_logic.implication: Temporary hit points are lost first. Any leftover damage carries over to normal hit points.
rule_logic.description_text: When you have temporary hit points and take damage, the temporary hit points are lost first, and any leftover damage carries over to your normal hit points.
related_search_terms: how do temporary hit points work
taking damage with temporary hit points

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule governing how temporary hit points interact with a creature's hit point maximum.

rule_logic.premise: Creature gains temporary hit points
rule_logic.implication: Temporary hit points can exceed the creature's hit point maximum. A character can be at full hit points and still receive temporary hit points.
rule_logic.description_text: Because temporary hit points are separate from your actual hit points, they can exceed your hit point maximum. A character can, therefore, be at full hit points and receive temporary hit points.
related_search_terms: can temporary hp go over max hp

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule clarifying the interaction between healing and temporary hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Creature attempts to restore temporary hit points via healing
rule_logic.implication: Healing cannot restore temporary hit points.
rule_logic.description_text: Healing can't restore temporary hit points, and they can't be added together.

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule determining how multiple sources of temporary hit points are handled.

rule_logic.premise: Creature has existing temporary hit points AND receives more temporary hit points from a new source
rule_logic.implication: Temporary hit points cannot be added together. The creature decides whether to keep the ones they currently have or gain the new ones.
rule_logic.description_text: If you have temporary hit points and receive more of them, you decide whether to keep the ones you have or to gain the new ones. For example, if a spell grants you 12 temporary hit points when you already have 10, you can have 12 or 10, not 22.

extracted_concepts.definition: A rule specifying the effect of receiving temporary hit points while at 0 hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Creature is at 0 hit points AND receives temporary hit points
rule_logic.implication: Receiving temporary hit points does not restore the creature to consciousness or stabilize them.
exceptions: Temporary hit points can still absorb damage directed at the creature while they are at 0 hit points.
rule_logic.description_text: If you have 0 hit points, receiving temporary hit points doesn't restore you to consciousness or stabilize you. They can still absorb damage directed at you while you're in that state, but only true healing can save you.

extracted_concepts.definition: The default duration for temporary hit points.

rule_logic.premise: Temporary hit points are granted by a feature that does NOT specify a duration
rule_logic.implication: Temporary hit points last until they are depleted OR the creature finishes a long rest.
exceptions: If a feature that grants temporary hit points specifies a duration, that duration applies instead.
rule_logic.description_text: Unless a feature that grants you temporary hit points has a duration, they last until they're depleted or you finish a long rest.
related_search_terms: how long do temporary hit points last
